metadata.case_name: Appellant (Private Limited Company) v. Respondent (Income Tax Authorities)

facts.text: The appellant is a private limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, carrying on business as marine engineers and ship repairers. Its registered office is in Bombay and it is resident and ordinarily resident in India.

The appellant's entire share capital is beneficially owned by two British companies, the P&O Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., and the British Indian Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., which are non-resident companies whose business consists in plying ships for hire.
Under an agreement with the two non-resident companies, the appellant repairs their ships at cost, and charges no profits.

The Income-tax Officer, Bombay, took the view that the appellant had so arranged its business with the non-resident companies that it did not produce any profits due to close connection, and computed deemed profits under s.42(2) at Rs. 6,80,000 for 1943-44, Rs. 4,67,559 for 1944-45, and Rs. 4,68,963 for 1945-46.
Orders of assessment made for income-tax for 1944-45 and 1945-46, and excess profits tax for 1943-44, 1944-45, and 1945-46.
Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who confirmed the orders by order dated July 3, 1952.
Further appeal to Appellate Tribunal; Bench divided, President by order dated March 19, 1954, held s.42(2) inapplicable and set aside assessments.

On Department's application, Tribunal referred question: 'Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case any income falls to be included in the appellant's assessment under s.42(2)' to Bombay High Court.
Bombay High Court (Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.) by judgment dated February 24, 1955, held s.42(2) applicable and appellant liable.
Appellant applied for leave under s.66A to HC, dismissed; obtained special leave under Art.136 to Supreme Court.

For 1943-44 income-tax, initial assessment on Dec 31, 1948 excluded s.42(2) profits; later action under s.34, reassessment May 29, 1953 including them, appeal pending before AAC; not subject of present proceedings.
Present proceedings concern income-tax assessments for 1944-45 and 1945-46, and excess profits tax for 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on the facts found, the appellant is chargeable to tax under s.42(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.42(2) imposes a charge only on a business carried on by a non-resident, and therefore no tax could be imposed under that provision on the business of the appellant who is a resident.

It is a condition for the levy of a charge under s.42(2) that the non-resident must carry on business with the resident, and that condition is not satisfied as non-residents' business is plying ships and they merely get ships repaired by appellant.

respondent_arguments.text: s.42(2) applies to the business of the resident when due to close connection with non-resident, it produces no or less than ordinary profits; the word 'therefrom' refers to resident's business.
Non-resident companies carry on business with appellant within s.42(2) through special agreement for repairs at cost, constituting organised trading activities.

court_reasoning.text: Language of s.42(2) is plain: 'therefrom' refers to the business of the resident, not non-resident; charge on resident's business when it produces no/less profits due to close connection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The business which is the subject-matter of taxation under s.42(2) is that of the resident and not of a non-resident.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'profits derived therefrom or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived therefrom' relate to resident's business; rejects appellant's interpretation relying on 'derived', 'in the name of resident', 'deemed assessee'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ambiguity; resident taxed on deemed profits of its own business.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 34 of Income-tax Rules does not alter interpretation of s.42(2); context confirms resident's business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules cannot affect true interpretation of section.

court_reasoning.text: Non-resident companies carry on business with resident: under special agreement, send ships for repair at cost for use in their business; constitutes organised, continuous trading activities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.42(2) includes all activities between them having relationship to their business; 'business' construed broadly in fiscal statutes.

court_reasoning.text: Subject-matter is resident's business; immaterial if non-residents made no profits from arrangement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax on what resident would normally have made but for association.

holdings.text: s.42(2) taxes the business of the resident (not non-resident) when due to close connection, it produces no or less than ordinary profits.
Non-resident companies carried on business with appellant within s.42(2) through agreement for ship repairs.

precedents_cited.relevance: Broad connotation of 'business' or 'trade' in fiscal statutes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Business' connotes real, substantial, systematic or organised course of activity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Curimbhoy Ebrahim & Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Business connection' in s.42(1) different from 'business' in s.4.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Continuity of business relationship constitutes 'business connection'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bangalore Woollen, Cotton and Silk Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras

precedents_cited.relevance: Arrangement reducing costs not profit liable to tax; but irrelevant as tax on resident's business.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s.42(2) imposes charge on resident's business profits deemed due to close connection with non-resident; reference and appeal provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Rules, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Modes for determining profits under s.42; R.34 refers to s.42(2) but does not alter section's interpretation.

outcome.summary: The Court rejected both contentions of the appellant, held that s.42(2) applies to tax the appellant's business on deemed profits due to close connection with non-resident companies, and that the non-residents carried on business with the appellant; thereby upholding the High Court's judgment making the appellant liable for the assessments.

key_quotes.text: "Where a person not resident ... carries on business with a person resident in the taxable territories, and it appears to the Income-tax Officer that owing to the close connection between such persons the course of business is so arranged that the business done ... produces to the resident either no profits or less than the ordinary profits ... the profits derived therefrom, or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived therefrom, shall be chargeable to income-tax in the name of the resident".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Full text of s.42(2) central to interpretation.

key_quotes.text: The language of the enactment imposing the charge is too plain to admit of any doubt. ... 'therefrom' ... can refer only to the business of the resident, and it is this business therefore that is the subject of the charge under s.42(2).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on whose business is taxed.

key_quotes.text: The word business is ... one of wide import and in fiscal statutes, it must be construed in a broad rather than a restricted sense.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for finding non-residents carried on business with resident.
